metadata.titleEn: Benthic macroinvertebrate data of Tibet lakes (2020)
metadata.description: Through the semi-quantitative collection method, benthos research was carried out in 22 lakes in the core area of Qiangtang and Yamzho Lake in the summer of 2020. The relative abundance data of Zoobenthos in alpine lakes in Tibet were obtained by the mixed sampling of littoral and deep-water communities. The results of this data show that among the 6420 selected benthos, 28 species of benthos are identified, belonging to 3 phyla and 7 classes, of which the main benthic groups are gammarus and chironomid, and the dominant species in a few lakes are water beetles. This data improves the recognition accuracy and cognitive range of Zoobenthos in Tibet and will provide a reference for the evaluation of aquatic animal diversity and fishery resources in plateau lakes.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: the benthic data is stored in Excel format. The name of the file is "step_2020_lake benthos_%", in which the abscissa is the species name and the ordinate is the lake name.
Data reading method: the data can be opened, read and used directly with office software.

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used to study benthic animals in Tibetan lakes?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to study benthic animals in high-altitude lakes?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to study benthic animals in high-altitude lakes involves semi-quantitative sampling during the summer season. This approach includes mixed sampling of communities from both coastal and deep-water areas to gather relative abundance data of benthic fauna.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the semi-quantitative data collection method used to study benthic fauna in Tibetan lakes?
Feature Specification.Answer: coastal and deep-water zones, relative abundance data, 28 species, 3 phyla, 7 classes, amphipods, chironomids, water beetles

Definition.Question: What is the 'semi-quantitative collection method' used for gathering data on benthic animals in the context of high-altitude lakes?
Definition.Answer: The semi-quantitative collection method involves collecting samples from both the shoreline and deeper water zones to obtain relative abundance data of benthic animals in high-altitude lakes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a semi-quantitative data collection method in high-altitude lake benthic animal studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a semi-quantitative data collection method has resulted in the identification of 28 species of benthic animals in Tibetan lakes, with increased precision and understanding of these species. This method provided relative abundance data, aiding in the assessment of aquatic biodiversity and fishery resources in high-altitude lakes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed in the semi-quantitative sampling method to collect benthic organisms in high-altitude lakes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The semi-quantitative sampling method involves conducting research in the summer by sampling from both littoral and deep-water zones to obtain relative abundance data of benthic organisms in high-altitude lakes.
